headline: Teetering with Trump, Brooks calls for McConnell's ouster
sentences: During a closed-door fundraiser for Georgia gubernatorial candidate David Perdue at his Mar-a-Lago estate last week, Trump said Brooks “decided to go woke” — a reference to Brooks breaking with Trump by saying that the results of the 2020 election can’t be overturned — and that he was doing “terrible” in the primary, according to an attendee.

| Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
By Alex Isenstadt and Natalie Allison
 03/21/2022 04:31 AM EDT
Alabama Republican Mo Brooks is calling for Mitch McConnell to be ousted as Senate GOP leader, making him the party’s third major Senate candidate to come out in favor of booting the Kentucky Republican.

Brooks says in the spot that McConnell “will do everything he can to defeat me because he’s determined to stop the MAGA movement and Donald Trump’s endorsed candidates for the U.S. Senate,” and he challenges Britt and Durant to join him in supporting McConnell’s ouster.

Blake Masters, who is among the Republicans seeking Trump’s endorsement in Arizona’s Senate race, suggested last month that McConnell had an issue with him, but stopped short of saying the Kentucky Republican should lose his leadership position.

“America can’t afford a Senate leader who is a weak-kneed, debt junkie, open-border RINO Republican and who, worse yet, sells out America for special interest group cash,” Brooks says in a new 90-second web advertisement.

The Alabama race to replace retiring Sen. Richard Shelby is a three-way competition also featuring Katie Britt, Shelby’s former chief of staff, and Mike Durant, a defense contractor and former Army pilot.
In Alaska, the Trump-endorsed Tshibaka, who is challenging Republican Sen. Lisa Murkowski, has also said she supports McConnell’s removal and has called for new Republican leadership in the Senate.
All three are running staunchly anti-establishment campaigns and are aligning themselves with former President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly laced into McConnell over the past year.
Trump told the Washington Examiner last week that he was considering pulling his endorsement of Brooks, who has trailed his primary opponents in fundraising.
Brooks joins two other Republican candidates — Eric Greitens of Missouri and Kelly Tshibaka of Alaska — in pushing for McConnell’s removal.
While Trump has yet to endorse in the Missouri race, he has warmed to Greitens, at least in part because of his anti-McConnell posture.
Rep. Mo Brooks stands beside former President Donald Trump during a "Save America" rally in Cullman, Ala., on Aug. 21, 2021.
In the interview, Trump ripped Brooks for urging Republicans to move on from questioning the results of the 2020 election.
Last year, Greitens became the first GOP Senate candidate to vow he would oppose McConnell as leader, if elected.
Despite Trump’s encouragement, anti-McConnell sentiment has not caught on broadly among GOP Senate candidates.
Whether Brooks’ anti-McConnell offensive is enough to keep Trump from dropping his endorsement isn’t clear.
Both Masters and Vance are being supported by billionaire entrepreneur Peter Thiel, a Trump ally.
“Do you stand with grassroots conservatives or Mitch McConnell and the RINOs?” Brooks says.
Vance has said he isn’t sure whether he would support McConnell as leader.
And Brooks is releasing the ad at a treacherous moment for his campaign.
Other GOP Senate candidates have tip-toed around the issue.
A McConnell representative declined to comment.
